title: Autoencoders
content:
An Autoencoder is a type of artificial neural network used for unsupervised learning. Its primary goal is to learn an efficient, compressed representation (encoding) of input data.

The architecture of an autoencoder consists of two main parts:
1. Encoder: This part takes the input data and transforms it into a lower-dimensional representation, often called the latent space or code. This process compresses the input information.
2. Decoder: This part takes the compressed representation from the encoder and reconstructs the original input data from it.

The network is trained by minimizing the reconstruction error, which is the difference between the original input and its reconstructed output. By forcing the network to reconstruct its own input, it learns a meaningful and compact representation of the data in the latent space. Autoencoders are commonly used for dimensionality reduction, feature learning, anomaly detection, and even for generating new data (when combined with generative models).
